questions.text: Which of the following is an important epidemiological indicator for monitoring iodine deficiency in the Goiter Control program?

On examination, she has a well-circumscribed area of hair loss over her occipital region, as shown below. Which among the following is not a feature of the disease described?
questions.explanation: Ophiasis Sisaipho

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with a history of IV drug use presents with fatigue, nausea, and mild jaundice. He reports a history of similar symptoms about 5 years ago, which resolved spontaneously. Laboratory testing shows elevated liver enzymes, and an ELISA test is positive for anti-HCV antibodies. Which of the following tests would be most appropriate to confirm an active HCV infection in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Hepatitis C Virus (HCV)

Classification

HCV belongs to the Flaviviridae family, genus Hepacivirus.
 

Structure and Genome
  • Spherical, 60 nm, enveloped virus with a positive-sense single-stranded RNA (ssRNA).
  • Structural proteins: Core protein (C), envelope glycoproteins (E1, E2).
  • Nonstructural proteins: NS2, NS3, NS4A, NS4B, NS5A, NS5B.
  • P7 membrane protein (NS1) functions as an ion channel.
 

Transmission
  • Primarily bloodborne: Transfusions, organ transplants, needle-sharing.
  • Vertical transmission (~6%) & rarely sexual transmission.
  • Not spread by breast milk, food, or casual contact.
 

Clinical Manifestation
  • Incubation: 15–160 days (average 50 days).
  • Asymptomatic in over 75% of cases.
  • Acute hepatitis in ~20%: usually mild or anicteric

Chronic Progression

  • Chronic Disease: 75–85% of cases progress to chronic disease.
  • Chronic Hepatitis: 60–70% of chronic cases.
  • Cirrhosis: 5–20% of cases with chronic infection.
  • Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC): 1–5% of cases; HCV accounts for ~25% of liver cancers.
 

Extrahepatic Manifestations

Immune complex deposition can cause:

  • Mixed cryoglobulinemia
  • Glomerulonephritis
  • Arthritis and joint pain.

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • Antibody Detection Tests: ELISA is standard for initial screening with high sensitivity and specificity. Cannot differentiate active vs. past infections.
  • HCV Core Antigen Assay: Automated, cost-effective for active infection diagnosis and treatment monitoring. Less sensitive than RT-PCR. (Option A)
  • Molecular Methods (RT-PCR): Gold standard for confirming active infection; detects HCV RNA 2–3 weeks post-infection, used for viral load, treatment response, and genotype. (Option C)
  • Biopsy (Option B) is the gold standard for staging; Fibroscan (Option D) is a non-invasive alternative for assessing liver fibrosis.

Treatment
  • Goals: Prevent complications (e.g., cirrhosis, liver cancer) and achieve sustained viral response (SVR).
  • Sofosbuvir/velpatasvir is effective against all genotypes.
  • Duration: Typically 12–24 weeks, depending on genotype and liver status.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with recurrent infections and a history of autoimmune disease. Laboratory tests reveal a deficiency in complement component C3. Which of the following is the most likely consequence of this deficiency?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased susceptibility to infections by Neisseria meningitidis

options.label: B
options.text: Impaired opsonization and phagocytosis, leading to severe bacterial infections

options.label: D
options.text: Enhanced immune complex clearance and reduced inflammation

questions.correct_answer: B. Impaired opsonization and phagocytosis, leading to severe bacterial infections
questions.explanation:
Deficiency

Condition/Clinical Manifestation

C1 Inhibitor Deficiency (Option C ruled out)

Hereditary angioneurotic oedema: Uncontrolled activation of classical pathway causes episodic swelling (can be life-threatening).

C3 Deficiency

Increased susceptibility to severe recurrent pyogenic infections; impaired opsonization, phagocytosis, and immune complex clearance.

C5-C9 Deficiencies

Increased susceptibility to bacteraemia, especially with Gram-negative diplococci; impaired formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC).

questions.text: Match the following Delancey level of support of the uterus and the ligaments involved, and what condition it causes: Delancey Level of Support Ligaments Involved Conditions 1. Level 1 A. Pubocervical fascia and rectovaginal fascia I. Cystocele 2. Level 2 B. Levator ani muscle II. Enterocele 3. Level 3 C. Uterosacral and cardinal ligaments III. Urethrocele
questions.explanation:
DeLancey Level of Support

Ligaments Involved

Conditions

Level 1
  • Supported by uterosacral and cardinal ligaments
  • Supports the uterus and vaginal vault.
  • The cervix remains at or just above the ischial spines.

Damage can lead to:

  • Uterine descent
  • Enterocele
  • Vault descent

Level 2
  • Supported by pelvic fascia and paracolpos (vascular and connective tissues alongside the vagina).
  • Connects the vagina to the lateral pelvic wall through the arcus tendinous fascia pelvis.
  • Includes pubocervical fascia (anteriorly), rectovaginal fascia, and septum (posteriorly).

Damage can lead to:

  • Cystocele
  • Rectocele

Level 3
  • Supported by the levator ani muscle.
  • Supports the lower one-third of the vagina.
  • Forms a platform that compresses pelvic organs (uterus and upper vagina) during straining.

Damage can lead to:

  • Urethrocele
  • Gaping introitus 
  • Deficient perineum

A 6-month-old infant presents with severe hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, growth retardation, irritability, and lethargy between feedings. Laboratory tests reveal elevated lactate, triglycerides, and uric acid. The child frequently feeds to manage hypoglycemia. Based on these findings, which condition is most likely responsible for the symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Cause

Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme

Pathophysiology

Inability to convert glucose-6-phosphate to glucose; leads to accumulation of glycogen, lactate, and triglycerides

Symptoms
  • Severe hypoglycemia
  • Hepatomegaly and Renomegaly
  • Growth retardation
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hyperuricemia and Hyperlipidemia

Diagnosis
  • Biochemical tests (hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia)
  • Genetic testing

Management
  • Frequent feedings with slow-release carbohydrates
  • Blood glucose monitoring
  • Medications for associated conditions
  • Liver transplantation (in severe cases)

GSD Type Name Enzyme Deficiency Affected Organs Key Features
Type I Von Gierke's Disease Glucose-6-phosphatase Liver, Kidney Severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia
Type V McArdle's Disease (Option B ruled out) Muscle phosphorylase Skeletal Muscle Exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, myoglobinuria after exertion
Type VII Tarui's Disease (Option C ruled out) Muscle phosphofructokinase Muscle, RBCs Exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, hemolytic anemia
Type VI Hers' Disease (Option D ruled out) Liver phosphorylase Liver Hepatomegaly, mild hypoglycemia, milder symptoms than Von Gierke's

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida gave birth to a healthy baby boy of 4 kg. She sustained an injury to the perineum involving internal and external anal sphincters. Which degree of perineal tear is this?
questions.explanation:
Degrees of perineal tear

Description

First Degree (Option A)

Injury to perineal skin only.

Second Degree (Option B)

Injury to perineum involving perineal body (muscles) but not involving the anal sphincter.

Third Degree (Option C)

Injury to perineum, involving the anal sphincter complex (both external and internal):

  • 3a: <50% of EAS thickness torn
  • 3b: >50% of EAS thickness torn
  • 3c: Both EAS and IAS torn

Fourth degree (Option D)

Injury to perineum involving the anal sphincter complex (EAS and IAS) and anal epithelium.

questions.text: Which of the following is the CO2 absorption capacity of soda lime?
questions.explanation:
Function
  • Removes carbon dioxide through an exothermic reaction in a closed breathing circuit

Composition
  • Sodium hydroxide
  • Calcium hydroxide
  • Potassium hydroxide
  • Water

Granule size
  • 4 to 8 mesh size

Absorption capacity

  • Soda lime absorbs up to 23 L of CO₂ per 100 g of absorbent.

Chemical Process
  • Sodium and potassium hydroxide neutralize and trap carbon dioxide.
  • Gaseous carbon dioxide is converted into solid calcium carbonate (chalk).

By-products
  • Heat and water are produced during the reaction.
  • Helps maintain the temperature and humidity of the anesthesia circuit.

Indicator
  • A dye (e.g., ethyl violet) changes color from white to purple with increasing hydrogen ion concentration and absorbent exhaustion.

Reaction with anesthetics
  • Dry soda lime can degrade volatile anesthetics (e.g., desflurane, sevoflurane) and produce carbon monoxide.
  • Carbon monoxide formation is greatest with desflurane.

questions.text: Match the following herpes virus with its corresponding microscopic findings. 1. Herpes Simplex Virus A. 2. Epstein Barr Virus B. 3. Cytomegalovirus C. 4. Human herpes virus type 8 D.
questions.explanation:
Herpes simplex virus

  • Tzanck smear: Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained 'ground-glass' chromatin (Tzanck cells).
  • Formation of Lipschutz bodies (Cowdry type A).

EBV (Epstein Barr virus)

  • Downey cells: Atypical lymphocytes (large, vacuolated) are observed.
  • Ballerina skirt appearance.

CMV (Cytomegalovirus)

  • The presence of inclusion bodies gives the characteristic “Owl-eye appearance”.

HHV 8 (human herpes virus type 8)

  • Castleman disease: Onion skinning of lymphocytes and blood vessels, giving the appearance of “Lollipop follicles”.

questions.text: A patient is scheduled to undergo a Whipple procedure for the treatment of pancreatic cancer. The surgeon needs to perform anastomosis to reconstruct the digestive tract after removing the affected tissues. In which sequence are the anastomoses typically performed during a Whipple procedure?
questions.explanation:
Whipple’s procedure  (Pancreaticoduodenectomy)

Structures removed: Head of the pancreas, the first part of the small intestine (duodenum), the gallbladder, and a portion of the bile duct.

Types:

  • Pylorus-Preserving Whipple Procedure (Preferred)
  • Non–Pylorus-Preserving Whipple Procedure

Indications
  • Pancreatic Cancer: Commonly treated with Whipple if cancer is localized to the head of the pancreas.
  • Chronic Pancreatitis: when uncontrolled by medical management.
  • Tumors in Pancreas/Surrounding Areas: Includes duodenum, distal bile duct, and ampulla of Vater.

Procedure Steps
  • Tumor Assessment: Explore abdomen to assess tumor size, location, and spread.
  • Resection: Remove head of pancreas, duodenum, gallbladder, and part of bile duct; this may include partial stomach resection.
  • Lymph Node Dissection: Remove and examine nearby lymph nodes.

Reconstruction
  • Pancreaticojejunostomy: Connect remaining pancreas to jejunum.
  • Hepaticojejunostomy: Connect common bile duct to jejunum.
  • Gastrojejunostomy: Connect stomach to jejunum.

Anastomosis Principles
  • Tension-Free Connection: Achieve mucosa-to-mucosa connection for healing.
  • Order of Anastomoses: Pancreaticojejunostomy → Hepaticojejunostomy → Gastrojejunostomy
  • Stent Placement: May use internal/external stents for small ducts.

Complications
  • Pancreatic Fistula: Major issue; managed with somatostatin analogues.
  • Delayed Gastric Emptying
  • Bleeding, wound infection
  • Reoperation, increased mortality
  • Dumping/Bile Reflux: Common after non-pylorus-preserving Whipple; pylorus-preserving method has uncertain benefits.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents after a road traffic accident. He experienced a brief loss of consciousness, followed by a lucid interval. Subdural Hemorrhage (SDH) (Option A)

Type of Hemorrhage

Arterial Hemorrhage

Venous Hemorrhage
Shape

Biconvex or lentiform

Crescent or sickle-shaped

Location

Limited by sutures; can cross the midline

Follows the brain surface; crosses sutures, does not cross midline

Cause

Rupture of the middle meningeal artery (MMA)

Rupture of cortical bridging veins

Onset of Symptoms

Often presents with a lucid interval

Symptoms may develop gradually, often without a lucid interval

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with chronic diarrhoea, abdominal bloating, and unintended weight loss. She reports discomfort after consuming gluten-containing foods. Laboratory tests show elevated tissue transglutaminase (tTG) and anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA) levels, prompting a small intestinal biopsy via upper endoscopy. Which of the following combinations of histopathological features will be seen in this condition? Intraepithelial CD8+ T Lymphocytes Crypt hyperplasia Villous atrophy Decreased mitotic activity Inflammatory cell infiltration in lamina propria
questions.explanation:
Feature Seen in Celiac? Explanation
1. Intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes Yes Early and sensitive marker of immune response
2. Crypt hyperplasia Yes Compensatory response due to villous damage
3. Villous atrophy Yes Hallmark feature; leads to malabsorption
4. Decreased mitotic activity No Mitotic activity is increased, not decreased
5. Inflammatory cell infiltration in LP Yes Mainly lymphocytes and plasma cells in lamina propria

Definition

Autoimmune disorder triggered by ingesting gluten-containing foods in genetically susceptible individuals.

Synonym
  • Gluten-sensitive enteropathy
  • Celiac sprue

Diagnosis
  • Biopsy of the second part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum

Serum markers
  • Anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG)-most sensitive
  • Anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA)-most specific

Histology

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant presents with recurrent ear infections, eczema, and petechiae. He has a history of prolonged bleeding from the umbilical stump. His complete blood count reveals thrombocytopenia with small platelets. Immunoglobulin levels show low IgM and elevated IgA and IgE. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome

Definition
  • Rare X-linked recessive disorder affecting males; characterized by eczema, thrombocytopenia, and immunodeficiency.

Genetic Basis
  • Caused by mutations in the WASP gene, affecting actin cytoskeleton in blood cells.

Clinical Features
  • Eczema: Develops within the first year; ranges from mild to severe.
  • Thrombocytopenia: Present at birth; leads to prolonged bleeding from the umbilical stump, easy bruising, petechiae, and purpura.
  • Immunodeficiency: Susceptible to infections (bacterial, viral, opportunistic); increased risk of autoimmune disorders and malignancies (lymphomas, leukemia).

Diagnosis
  • Clinical Triad: Eczema, thrombocytopenia, and immunodeficiency.
  • Lab Tests: CBC (small, abnormally shaped platelets), immunoglobulin levels (low IgM, high IgA and IgE), lymphocyte subset analysis (low T cells), genetic testing (WASP mutations).
  • Mnemonic: WATER-WASP gene mutation, Thrombocytopenia, Eczema, Recurrent infections

Treatment
  • Supportive Care: Preventative antibiotics, immunoglobulin replacement, eczema management, use of killed vaccines.
  • Curative Treatment: Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT)

Prognosis
  • Without HSCT: Often fatal in childhood due to infections, bleeding, or malignancies.
  • With HSCT: Can significantly improve life expectancy; risks include graft-versus-host disease (GvHD).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male agricultural worker from a rural area presents with an extensive slowly growing, warty, nodular lesion on his lower leg as shown in the image below. The lesion is dark, and rough, and resembles the surface of cauliflower. He recalls injuring his leg on a thorn while working barefoot in the fields several months ago. A KOH mount of the skin specimen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Chromoblastomycosis (Also known as verrucous dermatitis)

Epidemiology

It is the most common form of chromomycosis.

Common among barefoot agricultural workers and woodcutters.

Tropical region.

Causative agents

Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Fonsecaea compacta, Exophiala dermatitidis, Phialophora, Cladophialophora.

Route of transmission

Infecting fungi enter the skin by traumatic implantation.

Clinical manifestation

Warty, cutaneous nodular lesions (resemble the florets of cauliflower).

Usually confined to subcutaneous tissue of the feet and lower legs

Slow-developing lesions around the site of implantation.

Chromoblastomycosis foot" data-author="" data-hash="10182" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/XDM2CdVMChdG0KscAB1w1744476678.png" />

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy: The lesions show the presence of the fungus as round or irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septate, called sclerotic bodies (other names: muriform bodies, copper pennies, medlar bodies).

Sclerotic cells" data-author="" data-hash="10185" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/vw70kUv1HY15bZZnjgC31744476801.png" />

Demonstration of these sclerotic bodies in KOH mounts or tissue sections, and by culture on Sabouraud agar.

Treatment

Medical: Amphotericin B, thiabendazole, 5-fluorocytosine, itraconazole and (new drug) voriconazole.

Surgical excision.

Characterized by the elevated risk of thromboembolism in advanced cancers, driven by tumour-associated inflammation, coagulation factors (such as tissue factor and factor VIII), and procoagulants like mucin released by tumour cells.

Carpopedal spasms, which are involuntary muscle contractions of the hand and wrist, can occur when a blood pressure cuff restricts circulation to the distal arm for several minutes. This phenomenon is indicative of hypocalcemia.

Type

Features

Perianal abscess (60%)(Option A ruled out)
  • Most common type; involves the suppuration of anal glands or infected perianal conditions
  • Located near the external sphincter.

Ischiorectal Abscess (30%)

(Option B ruled out)
  • 2nd most common; occurs in the ischiorectal fossa due to poor vascularization;
  • Presents with tender swelling, fever;
  • Treated with surgical drainage.

Submucous Abscess (5%)
  • Occurs above the dentate line, presenting with aching anorectal pain
  • O/E tender swelling felt on the rectal exam;
  • Treated with antibiotics and drainage.

Supralevator Abscess

(Option D ruled out)
  • Uncommon
  • Mimics intra-abdominal lesions
  • Diagnosed by DRE
  • Treatment: The drainage method depends on the abscess origin;
    • Intersphincteric abscesses- drained rectally,
    • Ischiorectal abscesses- drainage through the ischiorectal fossa.
    • Intra-abdominal disease- the primary condition is treated first, with abscess drainage via the most direct route.

questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Description

Causative Agent

Klebsiella granulomatis bacterium

Clinical Presentation

Painless ulcers or nodules in genital, perianal, or inguinal regions; ulceration with beefy red, granular base

Progression

Slowly progressive, may lead to extensive tissue destruction if untreated

Complications

Genital deformity, lymphatic obstruction, secondary bacterial infections

Diagnostic Tests

Tissue biopsy, Wright or Giemsa staining of tissue samples, PCR for bacterial DNA

Treatment

Doxycycline (200mg daily) or azithromycin (1g once a week)for 3 weeks

Characteristic

questions.text: A male presents with a painful 2.5 cm ulceroproliferative growth on the right lateral border of the tongue with induration extending to the floor of the mouth and a single, firm, mobile 1.5 cm lymph node palpable in the right submandibular region. The CT scan shows no mandible or extrinsic muscle involvement. What is the correct TNM staging for this patient?
questions.explanation:
T (Primary Tumor):

  • Tx: Primary tumor cannot be assessed.
  • Tis: Carcinoma in situ.
  • T1: Tumor ≤2 cm, ≤5 mm depth of invasion (DOI).
  • T2: Tumor ≤2 cm, DOI >5 mm and ≤10 mm; or tumor >2 cm but ≤4 cm, and ≤10 mm DOI.
  • T3: Tumor >4 cm; or any tumor >10 mm DOI.
  • T4a: Moderately advanced local disease - Invades through cortical bone, deep/ extrinsic muscle of tongue, maxillary sinus, or skin of the face.
  • T4b: Very advanced local disease - Invades masticator space, pterygoid plates, skull base, or encases internal carotid artery.

N (Regional Lymph Nodes):

  • Nx: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed.
  • N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.
  • N1: Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, ≤3 cm in greatest dimension.
  • N2:
    • N2a: Metastasis in a single ipsilateral node, >3 cm but ≤6 cm in greatest dimension.
    • N2b: Metastasis in multiple ipsilateral nodes, all ≤6 cm).
    • N2c: Metastasis in bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, all ≤6 cm.
  • N3:
    • N3a: Metastasis in a lymph node >6 cm in greatest dimension, ENE(-).
    • N3b: Metastasis in any node(s) with clinically overt ENE(+).

M (Distant Metastasis):

  • M0: No distant metastasis
  • M1: Distant metastasis

Stage 0

Tis N0 M0

Stage I

T1 N0 M0

Stage II

T2 N0 M0

Stage III

T3 N0 M0 or T1-3 N1 M0

Stage IVA

T4a N0-1 M0 or T1-4a N2 M0

Stage IVB

Any T N3 M0 or T4b Any N M0

Stage IVC

Any T Any N M1

Match the following: Biopsy Feature 1. FNAC a. Evaluation of cellular fibroadenoma 2. Core-needle biopsy b. Assessment of suspicious lymph nodes 3. Excisional biopsy c. Sampling solid masses, calcifications, and densities identified on imaging
questions.explanation:
Biopsy Type

Description

Indications

Limitations

Fine-needle aspiration (FNA)

22-gauge needle
  • Evaluation of secondaries
  • Assessment of suspicious lymph nodes
  • Cannot differentiate between noninvasive and invasive lesions if malignant cells are found
  • Requires core needle biopsy (CNB) for definitive histologic diagnosis
  • May yield inconclusive results

Core Needle Biopsy (CNB)
  • Preferred method
  • Imaging guidance
  • Needle: 8 to 14-gauge
  • Sampling solid masses, calcifications, and densities identified on imaging
  • Used to obtain histologic subtype, grade, and receptor status of detected malignancies
  • Small sample size requires careful interpretation
  • Inconclusive results may necessitate surgical excision

Excisional Biopsy
  • Entire lesion removed for diagnosis
  • Used when CNB results are inconclusive or when there is discordance with imaging findings
  • Evaluation of atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) or cellular fibroadenoma
  • Costly
  • Delays definitive treatment
  • More invasive

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, living in a malaria-prone area, presents with fatigue, jaundice, dark urine, and recent consumption of fava beans. Lab tests show hemolytic anemia. How does glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency lead to the observed symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced NADPH impairs glutathione regeneration, causing hemolytic anemia.

options.label: B
options.text: Increased ribulose-5-phosphate overloads nucleotides, leading to renal failure.

options.label: C
options.text: Impaired glucose-6-phosphate conversion disrupts glycolysis, causing hypoglycemia.

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased ATP production affects muscle function, causing myopathy.

questions.correct_answer: A. Reduced NADPH impairs glutathione regeneration, causing hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man recently lost his spouse and has been experiencing a profound sense of loss, sadness, and withdrawal from social interactions. This emotional response occurs following the death of a loved one and includes a natural period of adjustment. What term best describes his condition?
questions.explanation:
Term

Definition

Characteristics

Bereavement

State of having lost someone close, typically due to death.

Involves emotional and psychological responses; natural adjustment period; mild, transient functional impairment. Rarely involves severe symptoms like guilt or suicidal ideation.

Mourning

(Option A)

The outward expression and rituals associated with grief after a loss.

Includes cultural and personal expressions of grief; may involve ceremonies, rituals, and social mourning practices.

Adjustment Disorder

(Option B)

A condition characterized by difficulty coping with a significant life stressor.

Emotional or behavioral symptoms occur within three months of the event; can lead to distress and impaired functioning but not a normal grieving process.

Depression

(Option C)

A mental health disorder marked by persistent sadness and loss of interest in activities.

Symptoms include severe sadness, worthlessness, suicidal thoughts, and lack of interest; distinct from normal bereavement processes.

Night-Eating Syndrome (NES)

Absent or impaired (amnesia common)

Late evening or during night awakenings

During sleep, often within parasomnia episodes

Involuntary

Normal food

Non-edible or dangerous items often consumed

May be comorbid with sleep disorders

Start iron chelation

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady comes to the emergency department with muscle weakness, fatigue, and abdominal pain, and on evaluation, has some memory loss. Her lab reports show elevated serum calcium levels (13mg%), and she is diagnosed with primary hyperparathyroidism. Which of the following is the preferred treatment in this scenario?
Which of the following methods of suffocation is most commonly associated with a reflex vagal inhibition that can lead to sudden cardiac arrest?
questions.explanation:
Methods of Suffocation

Features

Smothering

(Option A ruled out)
  • Definition: Closing the nose and mouth using hands or foreign substances (e.g., mud, cloth).
  • Autopsy Findings:
    • External: Pallor may be present around the mouth/nose, pressure marks, distinct nail marks, petechiae, contusion on the inner lip, and stains on the bedding.
    • Internal: Potential internal organ haemorrhages.

Gagging (Option B ruled out)
  • Definition: Asphyxia caused by a cloth or material obstructing the mouth and nose.
  • Mechanism: A gag can block the pharynx, initially allowing nasal airflow. Obstruction worsens due to saliva and mucus, leading to complete airway blockage.
  • Symptoms:
    • Facial congestion.
    • Fine petechiae on the face, sclerae, and conjunctivae.
  • Intent: Always homicidal.

Choking

(Option C ruled out)
  • Definition: Airway obstruction due to an object lodged in the hypopharynx.
  • Accidental Choking: Often occurs during meals, especially while laughing or crying; vomited matter may be inhaled under intoxication or unconsciousness.
  • Immediate Symptoms: Acute respiratory distress; complications may develop later.
  • Autopsy Findings:
    • Thickened epiglottis and folds
    • Mucus accumulation in the throat.
    • Lungs exhibit interalveolar oedema, congestion, and haemorrhages.

Café Coronary
  • Definition: Sudden collapse and death while eating, often in intoxicated individuals.
  • Symptoms:
    • Cyanosis and violent coughing.
    • Collapse without significant distress.
  • Cause of Death: Reflex vagal inhibition leading to sudden cardiac arrest; high blood alcohol content anaesthetises the gag reflex. A poorly chewed food bolus may obstruct the larynx.
  • Autopsy Findings: Obstruction may be found in the mouth, larynx, or trachea, with food particles in mucus in the trachea/bronchi, differentiating from cases of post-mortem oesophagal food forcing. Signs of asphyxia may be absent.

  • Treatment: Heimlich Maneuver: Stand behind the patient, interlock fingers, and apply pressure to the stomach.

questions.text: A 45 y/o man from a tropical region presents with a painful red eye, significant watering, and sensitivity to light after working in a garden with decaying plant material. The patient is diagnosed with keratomycosis. Which of the following is not an examination finding in keratomycosis?

options.text: Feathery extensions at the margins of the corneal ulcer

questions.explanation:
Aspect

Description

Clinical Features

• Pain and foreign body sensation

• Watering of the eye

• Photophobia

• Blurred vision

• Redness

Typical Examination Findings

• Corneal Ulcer: Greyish-white, dry, with elevated rolled-out margins

• Pigmented Ulcer: Seen with dematiaceous fungi

• Feathery Extensions: Branching extensions into surrounding stroma (Option A)

• Sterile Immune Ring: Immune complex deposition (Option C)

• Satellite Lesions: Small lesions near main ulcer

• Hypopyon: Large, often non-sterile

• Endothelial Plaque: Dense accumulation of fibrin and leukocytes beneath lesion (Option D)

• Corneal Vascularization: Absent, especially in early disease (Option B is not seen)

Complications

• Rare corneal perforation

• Potential progression to endophthalmitis

Key Investigations

• Corneal Scraping: For smears and culture

• KOH Mount: Septate hyphae (Aspergillus, Fusarium) or yeast-like cells (Candida)

• Gram & Giemsa Stains: Inflammatory cells and fungal elements

• Culture: Sabouraud dextrose agar

• PCR: For early pathogen detection

• Confocal Microscopy: In vivo fungal visualization

• Anterior Chamber Paracentesis / Biopsy: If needed for deeper infection

questions.text: A 68 y/o female presents with a vulvar lesion on her labia majora. It measures 0.8 cm and has been present for several weeks. She reports persistent itching. What is the MOST appropriate investigation for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the vulva

Site
  • Labia majora is the most common (60%).
  • Clitoris 2nd most common (15%).
  • Most common in 50-70 years age group

Presentation
  • Exophytic (outward-growing) and ulcerative (open sore) growth.

Symptom
  • Pruritus (most common): Often associated with an itch-scratch cycle.
  • Cancer cachexia (weight loss and muscle wasting).
  • Cancer pain.

Spread
  • Primarily spreads through the lymphatic system.
  • Vulvar lymphatics cross over at the midline, especially within 2 cm of the midline.
  • The inguinofemoral lymph nodes are the most commonly involved group.
  • Lymph node involvement significantly affects prognosis.

Investigations
  • Excisional biopsy (IOC): For lesions < 1 cm in size. Complete lesion removal and histological assessment, including invasion presence and depth. (Option C)
  • Incisional biopsy: For lesions ≥ 1 cm in size. (Option D)
  • Wedge biopsy.
  • Keyes punch biopsy.
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy: Assess lymph node involvement, particularly the inguinofemoral nodes.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in ocular cysticercosis?
questions.explanation:
PRAZIQUANTEL

MOA

Causes calcium ion influx into the tapeworm, resulting in paralysis, detachment from the intestine, and death.

At higher concentrations, it breaks down the tapeworm's outer layer.

Pharmacokinetics

Extensively metabolised in the liver (⇒ less bioavailability)

Uses

Highly effective for all human tapeworm infections, especially for T. solium cysticercosis, where larvae invade tissues like the muscles, and skin.

Adverse effects
  1. In neurocysticercosis, killing larval cysts in the brain can trigger inflammation, leading to seizures and ￪intracranial pressure.
  2. C/I in ocular cysticercosis due to the risk of intense inflammatory response, tissue damage, and vision loss

Intense vulvovaginal pruritus (out of proportion to the discharge), dyspareunia, splash dysuria

Generally not accompanied by itching or inflammation but may be associated with complications such as PID and pregnancy complications

Diagnosis

questions.text: Match the following vitamins with their respective functional assessment tests: 1. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) a) Measure urinary methylmalonic acid 2. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin) b) Measure transketolase activity in red blood cells 3. Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) c) Measure glutathione reductase activity in red blood cells 4. Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin) d) Measure activation of red blood cell transaminases with pyridoxal phosphate
questions.explanation:
Vitamin Functional Assessment Test Key Enzyme/Process Assessed Clinical Relevance
Vitamin B1 (Thiamin) Transketolase activity in RBCs Transketolase (Pentose Phosphate Pathway) Reduced activity indicates thiamin deficiency (e.g., Beriberi, Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome)
Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin) Glutathione reductase activity in RBCs Glutathione Reductase (FAD-dependent) Low activity suggests riboflavin deficiency, leading to oxidative stress disorders
Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) RBC transaminase activity (after PLP addition) Aminotransferases (ALT, AST) Decreased enzyme activity suggests B6 deficiency, leading to neuropathy and anemia
Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin) Urinary methylmalonic acid measurement Methylmalonyl-CoA Mutase Elevated levels indicate B12 deficiency, which can cause megaloblastic anemia and neuropathy

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with ongoing tearing and discharge from the right eye. Despite regular lacrimal sac massage and topical antibiotics, the symptoms persist. What is the next best step in management?

options.text: Continue lacrimal sac massage and antibiotics

questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Definition

Blockage of the nasolacrimal duct, usually at the valve of Hasner

Typical Age

Present from birth or early infancy

Symptoms

• Chronic tearing (epiphora)

• Discharge

• Recurrent conjunctivitis

First-Line Management

• Crigler massage to open the duct

• Topical antibiotics for infection

Indications for Probing

• Persistence beyond 6–10 months

• Repeated infections or failure of conservative therapy

Prognosis with Probing

>90% success if performed before 12–15 months

questions.text: A 10 year old boy with a history of Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder presents with tics that have developed over the past few months. The tics are moderate in severity but interfere with his social interactions and academic performance. Which of the following medications is the most appropriate treatment for managing his ADHD while minimizing the risk of exacerbating the tics?

A patient experiencing postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) is undergoing resuscitation due to active bleeding. Laboratory tests have shown a critically low fibrinogen level. What is the recommended target fibrinogen level for patients with active bleeding during postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.explanation:
Laboratory Evaluation

Description

Routine Laboratory Tests

Tests:

  • Complete blood count (including platelet count),
  • Type and crossmatch for multiple units of red blood cells,
  • Coagulation studies (fibrinogen concentration, prothrombin time, activated partial thromboplastin time).

Note: Hemoglobin levels drop by ~1 g/dL for every 500 mL of blood loss.

Fibrinogen Measurement
  • Fibrinogen levels drop earlier than other coagulation factors and are a sensitive indicator of ongoing blood loss.
  • Normal Range:
    • 350-650 mg/dL in pregnancy.
    • Levels below 200 mg/dL are associated with severe PPH and higher morbidity/mortality.
  • Target: Recommended to maintain fibrinogen levels >200 mg/dL, ideally >300 mg/dL in active bleeding.

Viscoelastic Testing:

TEG/ROTEM 

Thromboelastography (TEG) and rotational thromboelastometry (ROTEM).

  • Function: Assess global blood hemostasis by measuring clot development, stabilization, and dissolution.
  • Usage: Effective for guiding plasma and coagulation product therapy.
  • ROTEM Findings:
    • FIBTEM A10 (Amplitude at 10 minutes) ≤17 mm is suggestive of low fibrinogen levels.
    • Fibrin-based clot strength (FIBTEM) is an early indicator of bleeding severity. FIBTEM A5 <10 mm may indicate severe PPH.

questions.explanation:
Toxoplasmosis in pregnancy

Mother

Usually asymptomatic but can transmit the disease to the infant.

Infective form

Trophozoite crosses the placenta to infect the neonate.

Risk of transplacental infection based on time of infection of the mother

Transplacental infection can occur at any time during the pregnancy, but the gestational age influences the risk of transmission (Option D).

 

As the gestational age increases, the risk of transmission increases, but the severity of neonatal disease decreases.

 

Pre-pregnancy (Option B)

  • Very low chance of transmission (immunocompromised mother)
 

First trimester

  • Minimal risk of transmission (Option A).
  • If transmitted, it results in more severe fetal complications.
 

Third trimester

  • Maximum risk of transmission (Option C).
  • If transmitted, it is usually asymptomatic in newborns.

questions.text: A 2-day-old infant is evaluated for discharge from the eyes. The discharge was initially serous, but it quickly turned into mucopurulent and then purulent. On examination, the eyes are bright red and swollen. What is the most likely causative agent here?
questions.explanation:
Definition

  • Ophthalmia neonatorum or neonatal conjunctivitis is a mucoid, mucopurulent, or purulent discharge from one or both eyes in the first month of life.
  • Any discharge, even watery, from a baby’s eyes in the first week of life must be viewed under suspicion as tears are not secreted so early in life.






 

Aetiology of ophthalmia neonatorum

Mode of infection:

  • Before birth:
    • Very rare through infected liquor amnii
  • During birth:
    • From an infected birth canal
  • After birth:
    • During the first bath of a newborn
    • Soiled clothes
    • Fingers with infected lochia
 

Source of infection:

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae:
    • Transmitted at the time of delivery
    • Presents between 2-5 days of birth
    • The discharge becomes mucopurulent and purulent quickly
    • Inflamed, bright red, swollen conjunctiva
    • Thick yellow pus and marked chemosis
    • Cornea seen at the bottom of a crater-like pit in severe cases
    • Bulbar conjunctiva & lids: dense infiltration, swollen and tense
    • Free flow of pus, serum, and often blood later
  • Chlamydia trachomatis: (Option A)
  • Transmitted at the time of delivery
  • Onset at 5-14 days after birth
  • Serotypes D to K are the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries
  • Characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies are seen
  • Less severe inflammation
  • Purulent discharge
  • Other causes:
    • Staphylococci
    • Streptococcus pneumoniae
    • Gram-negative coliforms
    • Herpes simplex virus
    • Chemical: silver nitrate solution previously used for prophylaxis immediately after birth (Option B): erythema, chemosis, lid edema, and discharge within the first 24 hours after birth.

 
 

Prophylaxis

  • Antenatal measures:
    • Treatment of genital infections and care of mother
    • Surveillance of pregnant women for STDs
  • Natal measures:
    • Aseptic, sterile precautions to be followed during deliveries
    • Clean the infant’s closed lids with sterile cotton soaked in normal saline and dried
  • Post-natal measures:
    • Povidone-iodine 2.5% solution
    • If the mother is under suspicion, 1% tetracycline or 0.5% erythromycin eye ointment is used in the baby immediately after birth and watched for a week.
    • Ceftriaxone 50mg/kg IM or IV single dose for infants born to mothers with untreated gonococcal infection.
  • Crede’s method:
    • Old method using 1% silver nitrate applied to infants' eyes right after birth
    • It is not used now as it can cause chemical neonatal conjunctivitis.

Diagnosis

Treatment

Neisseria gonorrhoea

Ceftriaxone IM, gentamicin drops, bacitracin eye ointment

Chemical

Wash eyes, erythromycin ointment, observe

Other bacteria

Neomycin-bacitracin ointment, gentamicin, or tobramycin drops

Herpes simplex virus

Acyclovir 3% eye ointment, systemic acyclovir (systemic involvement)

Chlamydia trachomatis

Erythromycin or chlortetracycline eye ointment, oral erythromycin (systemic infection)

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presented with a sudden onset of pain in the scrotum, groin, and lower abdomen. On examination of the scrotum, he is showing Deming’s sign. What is Deming’s sign?

options.label: A
options.text: The affected testis is positioned high

options.label: D
options.text: The affected testis is positioned low

questions.correct_answer: A. The affected testis is positioned high
questions.explanation:
Direction of Rotation
  • Right Testis: Rotates clockwise
  • Left Testis: Rotates counterclockwise

Predisposing Factors
  • Inversion of the Testis
  • High Investment of Tunica Vaginalis
  • Gap Between Testis and Epididymis
  • Heavy Straining

Features
  • Age Group: Common in children and adolescents
  • Symptoms: Sudden onset of pain in the scrotum, groin, and lower abdomen; vomiting due to pylorospasm
  • Signs: Tenderness, redness, and edema of the scrotal skin
  • Deming's Sign: Affected testis is positioned high due to twisting and cremaster muscle spasm
  • Angell's Sign: Opposite testis lies horizontally due to the presence of mesorchium

Investigations
  • WBC Count: Elevated levels
  • Doppler Study: To assess testicular artery pulsation
  • Ultrasound Abdomen

Treatment
  • Emergency Exploration: Scrotum exploration and untwisting of the testis. The viability of the testis is checked.
  • Fixation: If viable, the testis is fixed to the scrotal sac with 2-3 interrupted nonabsorbable sutures (Prolene).
  • Timing: If surgery occurs within 12-24 hours, viability may be retained. Any delay can lead to gangrene, requiring orchidectomy.
  • Orchidectomy Consideration: If in doubt, the testis can be retained temporarily, with orchidectomy postponed to assess viability.
  • Postoperative Care: A repeat Doppler study confirms viability. The opposite testis should also be fixed to prevent torsion.

A 35-year-old male, known to be HIV positive, presents with fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status. A lumbar puncture is performed to analyze his cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), and following microscopic findings are observed. What stain has been used here to visualize the organism?
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis of Cryptococcosis

Microscopy

  • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells
  • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture
  • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.
  • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.
  • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine
  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.
  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.
  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with a lifelong pattern of social withdrawal. He avoids social interactions, prefers to be alone, and shows no interest in forming close relationships. He appears emotionally distant and indifferent to praise or criticism. On examination, there are no signs of psychosis, delusions, or hallucinations. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Disorder

Key Features

Diagnosis

Treatment

Paranoid Personality Disorder (Option C ruled out)
  • Pervasive distrust and suspiciousness of others
  • Hostility, irritability, anger
  • Difficulty with trust and intimacy
  • Cynical view of world
  • No fixed delusions (vs. delusional disorder)
  • No hallucinations or formal thought disorder (vs. schizophrenia)
  • No tumultuous relationships (vs. borderline personality disorder)
  • No history of antisocial behavior (vs. antisocial personality disorder)
  • Psychotherapy: Straightforward and honest therapist, avoid warmth or deep interpretation
  • Group therapy: Helpful for some, but poorly tolerated
  • Behavior therapy: Social skills training, may feel intrusive

Schizoid Personality Disorder (Option B)
  • Lifelong social withdrawal
  • Eccentric, isolated, and lonely
  • Introverted with a bland affect
  • No psychotic symptoms (vs. schizophrenia, delusional disorder)
  • More withdrawn and aloof (vs. paranoid personality disorder)
  • No dysphoric loneliness
  • Fewer past relationships, possible autistic reverie
  • No desire for social interaction (vs. avoidant personality disorder)
  • Psychotherapy: Build trust, encourage expression
  • Group therapy: May benefit, initial silence likely
  • Pharmacotherapy: Limited evidence, medications for specific symptoms (e.g., emotional detachment)

Schizotypal Personality Disorder (Option A ruled out)
  • Social difficulties
  • Eccentric behavior and thinking (“magical thinking”)
  • Peculiar speech, superstitious beliefs, perceptual illusions
  • Odd behavior, thinking, and perception (vs. schizoid and avoidant personality disorders)
  • Differentiated from autism by the severity of language disorder
  • Lacks psychosis, or it's brief (vs. schizophrenia)
  • No odd behavior (vs. paranoid personality disorder)
  • Psychotherapy: Sensitive approach to avoid ridicule
  • Antipsychotics: Manage illusions and odd ideas
  • Antidepressants: Used for depressive symptoms

Disorder

Key Features

Diagnosis Criteria

Treatment

Paranoid Personality Disorder

Distrust, hostility, and suspicion

No delusions, hallucinations, or tumultuous relationships

Psychotherapy, group therapy, behavior therapy

Schizoid Personality Disorder

Social withdrawal, eccentric behavior

Absence of psychosis; does not desire social interaction

Psychotherapy, group therapy, limited pharmacotherapy

Schizotypal Personality Disorder

Eccentric behavior, perceptual oddities

Odd thinking, perceptual illusions, no psychosis

Psychotherapy, antipsychotics, antidepressants

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with suspected poisoning after ingesting an unknown substance. A toxicological analysis is performed, and the following specimens are collected: blood, urine, gastric contents, and liver tissue. Which of the following specimens is most crucial for detecting heavy metal poisoning analysis?
questions.explanation:
Specimen

Importance

Blood

Primary specimen; collect from femoral, iliac, or axillary veins to avoid contamination. (Option A ruled out)

Preservative: Lithium heparin or EDTA tube, fluoride/oxalate, if alcohol is

suspected

Urine

Useful for detecting parent compounds and metabolites of poisons. (Option B ruled out)

Preservative: No preservative, sodium fluoride is added, if alcohol is

suspected

Gastric Contents

Helps identify ingested poisons and their concentrations through vomitus and stomach contents analysis.

Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison.

Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid.

Liver

Analyzes metabolism and concentration of drugs; critical when blood/urine concentrations are low. Bile can detect specific substances like chlorpromazine and morphine. (Option D ruled out)

Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison.

Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid.

Hair and Nails

Detects heavy metal poisoning; metals accumulate in keratin. Neutron activation analysis identifies specific metals and exposure patterns. (Option C)

Scene Residues

Provides clues about the poison through materials found at the scene, such as tablets or empty containers.

Test Type

Description

Qualitative Tests

Determine presence/absence of specific drugs or toxins; positive indicates presence, negative suggests absence or low concentration.

Quantitative Tests

Measure specific concentration of drugs or toxins; crucial for assessing severity of toxicity for substances like acetaminophen, alcohols, barbiturates, and heavy metals.

questions.text: An 8-month-old baby is brought to the hospital after her mother noticed rashes all over the baby’s body, as shown in the image. The mother gives a history of syphilis during pregnancy. Which of the following is NOT an early onset sign of syphilis?
questions.explanation:
Early signs of congenital syphilis (within first 2 yrs of age)
  • Hepatosplenomegaly (Option C), Jaundice
  • Coombs-negative hemolytic anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Radiological findings:
    • Osteochondritis (Option B) and Periostitis: Painful and refusal to move the affected limb leading to pseudoparalysis of Parrot.
    • Wimberger’s corner sign is a specific radiographic finding where localized bony destruction to the medial side of the proximal tibia metaphysis is seen.
  • Mucocutaneous rash (Option A):
    • Characterized by erythematous maculopapular or vesiculobullous lesions, often followed by desquamation.
    • Often involves hands and feet

  • Mucous patches: Highly infectious, with high concentrations of spirochetes
  • Persistent rhinitis (snuffles)
  • Condylomatous lesions: Highly infectious
  • Failure to thrive, Chorioretinitis, Nephritis, Nephrotic syndrome can also be seen
  • Less common manifestations: Gastroenteritis, peritonitis, pancreatitis, pneumonia, eye involvement (glaucoma and chorioretinitis), nonimmune hydrops, and testicular masses.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male was admitted to the ICU after a motorcycle accident with a femur fracture 24 hours ago. He is confused, has a petechial rash, tachycardia (HR 120), tachypnea (RR 28), and an oxygen saturation of 65%. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Fat Embolism

Fat embolism is a multi-organ disorder caused by fat globules entering the bloodstream, commonly occurring after high-risk orthopedic injuries, particularly femur fractures.

Classic Triad
  • Hypoxia
  • Petechiae
  • Altered mental status

Other Symptoms

Tachycardia, fever, anemia, thrombocytopenia, pulmonary dysfunction (e.g., tachypnea, respiratory acidosis).

Etiology
  • Young adults (20-30 years): Long bone fractures
  • Iatrogenic cause: Occurs after reamed intramedullary (IM) nailing of the femur.

Pathogenesis

Following injury, fat from bone marrow or platelet agglutination enters injured vessels and travels as emboli, leading to various clinical manifestations.

Investigation
  • Chest X-ray: Snowstorm appearance (pathognomonic).

 

  • PaO₂ <60 mm Hg.
  • Platelet count <1.5 lakhs.
  • ECG: Prominent S-wave
  • Other lab findings: Anemia, hypocalcemia.
  • CT scan and MRI: Assess severity.

Management

  • Respiratory support: Oxygen or ventilator support to restore PaO₂.
  • Drug therapy:
    • Steroids: Reduce lung inflammation and improve gas exchange.
    • Heparin: Lipolytic and antiplatelet agent.
    • Low molecular weight dextran: Increases plasma volume.
    • Antibiotics and other supportive care.
  • Definitive fracture treatment: Early fixation to prevent worsening.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman is brought to ER for acute onset confusion, seizures, and behavioral changes for the past 2 days. She has a past history of hypothyroidism for which she is on levothyroxine. On exam: BP 130/80 mmHg, HR 84/min, Temp 37.1°C. Neurological exam reveals altered sensorium and generalized hyperreflexia. TSH is mildly elevated, T4 is low and T3 is low. CSF shows elevated protein with normal cell count. MRI brain is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A stillborn baby was noted to have the following findings. The above pathology is derived from which among the following structure shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Origin and Migration of Primordial Germ Cells (PGC)

2nd week:

  • PGC originate in the epiblast and migrate through the primitive streak.

3rd week:
  • They are located among endoderm cells in the wall of the yolk sac, close to the allantois.

4th week:
  • The PGC migrate by ameboid movement along the dorsal mesentery of the hindgut.

5th week:
  • They arrive at the primitive gonads.

6th week:
  • Invade the genital ridges.

Gonads
  • Shortly before and during the arrival of primordial germ cells, the epithelium of the genital ridge starts to proliferate.
  • Epithelial cells penetrate the underlying mesenchyme, forming primitive sex cords, which are irregularly shaped.
  • In both male and female embryos, the primitive sex cords are connected to the surface epithelium.
  • At this stage, the gonad is called the indifferent gonad, as there is no distinction between male and female gonads yet.

Pathologies associated: due to failure of migration of PGC
  • Teratoma (oropharyngeal/sacrococcygeal)
  • Non development of gonads

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive bilateral vision loss over the past few months. He reports a history of heavy smoking and alcohol consumption. Examination reveals a centrocecal scotoma in both eyes, and fundoscopy shows mild temporal pallor of the optic discs, as shown in the image. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.explanation:
Category

Agents

Mechanism of Action

Exogenous Poisons

Tobacco (Cyanide), Ethyl Alcohol (Ethanol), Methyl Alcohol (Methanol), Ethylene Glycol (Antifreeze), Lead, Arsenic, Cannabis indica (Tetrahydrocannabinol), Carbon Disulfide (Industrial Solvent)

These toxins directly affect optic nerve function through mitochondrial dysfunction or systemic toxicity.

Medications

Digoxin, Disulfiram, Isoniazid, Chloroquine, Cyanide, Ethambutol, Quinine, Streptomycin, Amiodarone, Sulfasalazine, Vigabatrin

These drugs interfere with cellular metabolism or have neurotoxic effects on the optic nerve, leading to vision loss.

Nutritional Deficiency

B Vitamins (especially B12, Thiamine, Folate)

Deficiencies in these vitamins lead to nerve damage, including the optic nerve.

Metabolic Disorders

Diabetic ketoacidosis, Uremia

These conditions cause metabolic disturbances that can damage the optic nerve.

questions.text: Which oral anticoagulant is known for inhibiting activated Factor Xa and is used for prophylaxis and treatment of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)?
questions.explanation:
Category

Direct Factor Xa Inhibitors

Direct Thrombin Inhibitors

Mechanism of action

Inhibit Factor Xa directly

Inhibit thrombin (Factor IIa) directly

Drugs

Apixaban, Rivaroxaban, Edoxaban, Betrixaban

Dabigatran, Ximelagatran

Uses

  • Prophylaxis of venous thromboembolism following knee or hip replacement surgery.
  • Prophylaxis of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation.
  • Treatment of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

Advantages of novel anticoagulants over warfarin
  • Rapid onset and offset of action.
  • No need for routine laboratory monitoring.
  • Lower risk of bleeding.
  • Fewer drug interactions.

questions.text: In the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform, which of the following statements accurately describes the "c wave"?

options.label: A
options.text: The "c wave" is caused by atrial systole

options.label: B
options.text: The "c wave" arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

options.label: C
options.text: The "c wave" corresponds to the rise in atrial pressure as blood fills the atria

options.label: D
options.text: The "c wave" is influenced by the fluctuations in venous pressure caused by respiration

questions.correct_answer: B. The "c wave" arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction
questions.explanation:
a wave
  • Caused by atrial systole. (Option A ruled out)
  • Atrial contraction results in a temporary halt in venous inflow.
  • Some blood flows back into the veins, causing a rise in venous pressure.

c wave
  • Arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction. (Option B)
  • Pressure is transmitted through the closed and bulging tricuspid valve.

x descent
  • Ventricular systole pulls the tricuspid valve down

v wave
  • Corresponds to the rise in atrial pressure as blood fills the atria. (Option C ruled out)
  • Occurs during diastole while the tricuspid valve is still closed.

y descent
  • Opening of tricuspid valve causing emptying of right atrium into ventricle

questions.text: Which of the following signs is seen in Arteriovenous fistula?
Which of the following is true about the rate-limiting step of the urea cycle?

options.label: A
options.text: It involves the formation of citrulline from ornithine.

options.label: B
options.text: It is catalysed by carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I).

options.label: C
options.text: It is regulated by argininosuccinate synthetase.

options.label: D
options.text: It is controlled by the enzyme argininosuccinate lyase.

questions.correct_answer: B. It is catalysed by carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I).
questions.explanation:
Reactions in the Urea Cycle

Step

Reaction Details

Enzyme Involved and Location

Key Points

Carbamoyl Phosphate Formation
  • Formation of carbamoyl phosphate from ammonia and CO₂ using ATP.
  • Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase I (CPS I)
 
  • Mitochondria
  • The rate-limiting step of the urea cycle.
  • Irreversible and allosterically regulated by N-acetyl glutamate (NAG).

Citrulline Formation (Option A)
  • Transfer of carbamoyl phosphate to ornithine to form citrulline.
  • Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC)
     
  • Mitochondria
  • Citrulline moves from mitochondria to cytosol for further processing in the urea cycle.

Argininosuccinate Formation (Option C)
  • Citrulline combines with aspartate to form argininosuccinate.
  • Argininosuccinate Synthetase
 
  • Cytoplasm
  • Requires ATP.
  • Links the urea cycle with the TCA cycle via aspartate.

Argininosuccinate Cleavage (Option D)
  • Cleavage of argininosuccinate into arginine and fumarate.
  • Argininosuccinate Lyase
 
  • Cytoplasm
  • Fumarate enters the TCA cycle, providing a connection between the urea cycle and other metabolic pathways.

Arginine Cleavage to Ornithine and Urea
  • Hydrolysis of arginine to produce ornithine and urea.
  • Arginase
 
  • Cytoplasm
  • Ornithine is recycled back into the urea cycle.
  • Urea is excreted by the kidneys, with some urea also entering the intestine.

Fate of Urea
  • Urea is transported to the kidneys, filtered, and excreted in urine.
  • Kidneys/ Intestine
  • Urea excretion is the final step, removing excess nitrogen from the body.

questions.text: A 10-year-old schoolboy was playing on the monkey bars during recess when he suddenly slipped and fell onto his outstretched hand. He immediately felt intense pain in his wrist. On examination, there is significant swelling and tenderness over the wrist. An X-ray of the wrist reveals specific findings indicative of a fracture. Based on the history, clinical features, and X-ray findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Torus fractures, also known as buckle fractures, occur when the periosteum (the outer layer of the bone) buckles or compresses, typically due to axial loading forces. This type of fracture is incomplete.


 

Common Sites
  • Most frequently affects long bones, especially the tibia (particularly the lower end near the metaphysis, where bones are more spongy and susceptible to compression).
  • The radius is another common site, particularly in falls involving outstretched hands (FOOSH injuries).

Clinical Features
  • There is minimal swelling and pain over the affected site.
  • Unlike complete fractures, there is no visible bone displacement.

Diagnosis

Radiographs show a subtle buckling of the cortex, but there is no break in bone continuity. The imaging may require careful interpretation to differentiate from complete fractures.

Treatment
  • Immobilization with a plaster of Paris (POP) slab for 4–5 weeks is usually sufficient.
  • Surgery is not needed, as these fractures typically heal well with conservative treatment. Follow-up may include monitoring for any signs of healing or complications.

Definition

An avulsion fracture occurs when a tendon or ligament pulls off a piece of bone from its insertion site due to sudden, forceful traction or contraction of the attached muscle.

Avulsion fracture of ACL

Common Sites
  • Tibial Tuberosity: The most common site, often associated with Osgood-Schlatter disease or sports-related injuries.
  • Tendo Achilles (Achilles tendon): Avulsion can occur due to excessive tension or a sudden contraction, especially during sports like running or jumping.

Clinical Features
  • Sudden onset of pain at the site of tendon insertion.
  • Swelling and limited movement are often observed.
  • The patellar tendon is frequently involved, and the small bone fragment pulled by the tendon may fail to reunite properly, leading to non-union.

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis is often made based on clinical evaluation and imaging.
  • X-rays may show a small bony fragment at the site of tendon insertion, confirming the avulsion.

Treatment
  • Small fractures are typically treated with rest and immobilization.
  • Larger fragments or cases with non-union often require surgical fixation using mini-screws, followed by immobilization to allow for healing.

Definition

An impacted fracture occurs when the broken ends of the bone are driven into each other, resulting in the telescoping of the fragments. This type of fracture may be difficult to detect on X-ray due to minimal displacement.

Common Sites
  • Neck of the Femur: The most commonly affected site, often seen in older adults following a fall.
  • The proximal fragment (head of the femur) is driven into the distal fragment (neck), creating the characteristic impacted fracture.

Clinical Features
  • Patients often experience pain in the groin or hip area and have difficulty bearing weight.
  • There may be a limited range of motion in the affected joint.

Diagnosis

Due to the telescoping of bone fragments, X-rays may show minimal fracture lines, requiring a careful radiographic assessment to ensure an accurate diagnosis.

Treatment
  • Disimpaction of the fracture is crucial and is typically done through gentle manipulation to separate the fragments.
  • If the blood supply to the femoral head is intact, the fracture can be internally fixed using screws or a plate to stabilise the bone and promote healing.

questions.text: According to the system, which has the logo below and under the Central Birth and Death Registration Act, 1969, what is the time limit for registering for birth and death events in India?

A female patient came with a history of vesicles and bullae in the flexural parts one week ago. She presented to a dermatology clinic today because the lesion has changed. On examination, the following lesion is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis

Key Features

Pemphigus vegetans (Option D)

Vegetating erosions in flexures; post-vesicular phase; cerebriform tongue (Premlata sign); Neumann/Hallopeau types.

Pemphigus foliaceus (Option A)

Crusted erosions in seborrheic areas (face, chest, scalp); no mucosal involvement; superficial blistering.

Endemic PF (fogo selvagem) (Option B)

Seen in rural Brazil/Colombia; associated with black fly bites (Simulium); affects children/young adults.

Condyloma acuminata (Option C)

HPV-related genital warts; soft, pink, verrucous or filiform lesions; no vesicle-bullae history.

Condyloma lata (secondary syphilis)

Flat, moist, broad-based lesions in groin/perineum; painless; seen in syphilis- not relevant here.
